nodes.text: A land price bubble can exist even when observed housing rent to price ratio (housing yield) is constant and non-vanishing, provided one distinguishes pure land rent from housing-structure rent
The distinction between rent accruing to housing structure and pure land rent is essential; failing to separate them can mask land bubbles

We analyze a two-period overlapping generations model with consumption good and housing service, Cobb-Douglas preferences, unit supply of durable non-reproducible land, and a representative firm producing perishable housing structure from construction material and land

Assumption: the housing production function F(M,X) is homogeneous of degree one, continuously differentiable with positive partials, concave, and satisfies lim M->0 (FX/FM)(M,1)=0 (an Inada-type condition)
From utility maximization and market clearing, optimal expenditures imply land price equals Pt = beta_o * e_t (where beta_o is preference weight on old consumption and e_t is endowment when young)
Proposition 1: Aggregate housing rent to land price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equal to beta_h / beta_o (beta_h is preference weight on housing service)

Proposition 2: The model has a unique equilibrium characterized by the first-order conditions and market clearing, and a land bubble exists if and only if the sum over time of FX/F evaluated at equilibrium Mt is finite (sum_t FX/F(Mt,1) < infinity)
Specialization: Consider CES production F with elasticity of substitution sigma and parameters A, alpha; empirical evidence suggests sigma > 1 for housing production

Proposition 3: For CES F with sigma > 1, there is a land bubble iff sum_t e_t^{1/sigma - 1} < infinity; in particular, with sustained economic growth e_t ~ G^t (G>1), the condition holds and land bubbles inevitably emerge
Dividend-yield relation used in proofs: Dt/Pt = (beta_h / beta_o) * (FX / F)(Mt,1), linking the dividend yield to the FX/F term and preference parameters
Bubble characterization lemma (background): An asset price exhibits a bubble iff the infinite sum of dividend yields sum_t Dt/Pt is finite (Montrucchio 2004 lemma / Santos and Woodford framework)

Conclusion: Observed stationarity or constancy of aggregate housing rent-to-price ratio does not rule out an endogenous land price bubble because housing yield can be driven by structure rent while pure land dividend yield may vanish

Implication for empirical work: One cannot dismiss land bubbles using aggregate housing price-rent stationarity; empirical analysis must separate pure land rent from housing-structure rent to detect land bubbles

Limitation / modeling simplification: The model assumes housing is perishable and fully depreciates each period, construction materials equal the consumption good, unit supply of land, and Cobb-Douglas preferences with specific timing of housing consumption
